newsitem.title: USA: BASKETBALL-CARRIL, HASKINS AND DIAZ-MIGUEL MAKE HALL OF FAME.
newsitem.headline: BASKETBALL-CARRIL, HASKINS AND DIAZ-MIGUEL MAKE HALL OF FAME.

text.p: Current Texas-El Paso coach Don Haskins, former Princeton coach Pete Carril and Spanish coaching legend Antonio Diaz-Miguel were among seven individuals inducted Monday into the Basketball Hall of Fame.
Joining Carril, Haskins and Diaz-Miguel were Denver Nuggets standout Alex English, 12-year NBA player Bailey Howell and women's stars Denise Curry and Joan Crawford.
The inductees needed 18 of 24 votes from the Honours Committee for induction. Enshrinement ceremonies will be held here on September 29.

Haskins accelerated integration in U.S. college basketball in 1966 when Texas-El Paso, then called Texas Western, started five black players and beat Kentucky in the NCAA Championship game. Kentucky, coached by the legendary Adolph Rupp, had an all-white starting five.
In his 35 years at the school, Haskins has compiled a 687-322 record.

Carril became a legend during his 29 years at Princeton after arriving at the Ivy League school in 1967. He is the only coach to record 500 victories at the Division I level without the benefit of athletic scholarships. His disciplined, fundamental style brought fear into almost every big-name programme that the Tigers played in the NCAA Tournament.
Diaz-Miguel coached the Spanish national team for 27 years and six Olympiads, capturing a silver medal in the 1984 Olympics at Los Angeles.

His teams were in 14 European championships and four world championships, placing second in 1973 and 1983 and third in 1991. He coached six European All-Star teams in the 1980s and is one of the pioneers of promoting basketball in Europe.

English, an eight-time All-Star, was the first player in NBA history to score 2,000 points in eight straight seasons. He ranks ninth all-time with 25,613 career points and was the leading in the decade of the 1980s with 19,682 points.

Howell, nominated by the veteran's committee, was a standout player for 12 years with the Detroit Pistons, Baltimore Bullets, Boston Celtics and Philadelphia 76ers from 1959-71. He finished with 17,770 points and 9,383 rebounds.

Curry was a four-year starter and a three-time All-America at UCLA from 1978-81. She averaged 24.6 points and 10.1 rebounds and is still the school's all-time leading scorer and rebounder with 3,198 points and 1,310 rebounds.

Crawford was a star of the Amateur Athletic Union from 1957-69, playing one season with Detroit and 12 in her hometown of Nashville. A 5-11 (1.80 m) centre was named to the All-America team all 13 seasons and helped Nashville win 10 championships.
